title: 107_hr379
content: The "Public School Construction Partnership Act" may be cited as the short title. Qualified public educational facility bonds are treated as exempt facility bonds. Qualified public educational facilities are now included as exempt facility bonds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These facilities are defined as school facilities owned by a private, for-profit corporation that are part of a public elementary or secondary school. Public-private partnership agreements involve private, for-profit corporations constructing, rehabilitating, or equipping school facilities under an agreement with a State or local educational agency. The corporation must transfer the facility to the agency at the end of the agreement term. The term "school facility" includes school buildings, related facilities, land, and properties used for educational purposes. Public schools are defined as elementary and secondary schools according to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines public schools as elementary and secondary schools. An issue will not be considered as described in subsection (a)(13) if the total face amount of bonds issued by the State exceeds a certain limit based on population or a set amount. The State may allocate the described amount in a calendar year as determined appropriate. Rules for carryforward of unused amount can be elected similar to section 146(f) rules, with the sole purpose being the issuance of exempt facility bonds. Amendment exempts certain bonds from general state volume caps. The amendment exempts certain bonds, including those for environmental enhancements of hydroelectric generating facilities and qualified public educational facilities, from limitations on land acquisition. Additionally, exempt facility bonds for qualified public-private schools are not subject to certain rules under section 147(h) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment exempts certain bonds, including those for environmental enhancements and qualified public educational facilities, from land acquisition limitations. It also exempts qualified public-private school bonds from certain rules under the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments apply to bonds issued after December 31, 2001. SEC. 3. Additional increase in arbitrage rebate exception for governmental bonds used to finance education facilities. The spending requirement for public school construction issue is amended to include a 4-year spending requirement where at least 10 percent of the available construction proceeds must be spent for governmental purposes within a 1-year period. The spending requirement for public school construction issue is amended to include a 4-year spending requirement where a percentage of proceeds must be spent within specific time periods. The term 'public school construction issue' refers to any construction issue where no bond is a private activity bond, and all construction proceeds are used for public school facilities for education below postsecondary level or for related land acquisition. The amendment increases the arbitrage rebate exception for governmental bonds used to finance education facilities from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000. This change applies to obligations issued after December 31, 2001. SEC. 4. Treatment of public school construction bonds as qualified tax-exempt obligations. Treatment of public school construction bonds as qualified tax-exempt obligations under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define what constitutes a qualified tax-exempt obligation for a tax-exempt obligation issued by a qualified small issuer after August 7, 1986, and designated for this purpose. The definition of a qualified small education bond issuer is amended to include any issuer with a reasonably anticipated amount of public school construction bonds issued during a calendar year. The amendments made by this section limit the amount of school construction bonds issued by a qualified small education bond issuer to $25,000,000 per calendar year. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 265(b)(3)(B)(ii) of the Code. These changes apply to obligations issued after December 31, 2001.
